question: Question_07
statement:
\textbf{Multiple Choice}

Let \emph{n} be the solution to the following ancient Indian problem
(taken from Rosen)

\emph{If eggs are removed from a basket 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 at a time,
there remain respectively, 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 eggs. But if the eggs are
removed 7 at a time, no eggs remain. What is the least number of eggs
that could have been in the basket?}

The number \emph{n} is congruent to which of the following modulo 13?

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  (a) 1
\item
  (b) 2
\item
  (c) 3
\item
  (d) 4
\item
  (e) None of the above.
\end{itemize}
sols:
The answer is \textbf{b = 2}.

The quickest solution is to note that adding one egg to the basket gives
a multiple of 2,3,4,5 and 6 and is congruent to 1 modulo 7. Since
$\displaystyle \text{lcm}(2,3,4,5,6) = 60$ we are simply looking for
multiples of 60 that are congruent to 1 modulo 7. Notice that
$\displaystyle 60 \equiv 4 \mod{7}$ and
$\displaystyle 120 \equiv 1 \mod{7}$. Hence the answer is
$\displaystyle 120 - 1 = 119$. reducing modulo 13 gives
$119 \equiv 2 \mod{13}$
hints:
For the quick solution, consider what happens when you add one egg to
the basket.

The slower way uses a more standard approach with the Chinese Remainder
Theorem.
